I believe the reason I did this was because I did not want him controlling the d file. Perhaps Ke6 might have been better since if he goes for the exchange, I can take with the king and that's where I'd really want him anyways. Guess I was also worried about the 4 vs 3 pawn structures on the king-side.

Sensing that he wanted to move his king to attack the queen-side (would take a while), I had two options - move my own king over (takes even longer) or mount a pawn attack on the king-side with the king and bishop for support. Note that his bishop is strong as long as I keep my pawns on white squares, so my imperative was to do a "dark side" attack, hehe.

Now, this move scared me *after* I made my move. I reacted (which is bad in a correspondence game) by simply toggling.

I realized if he posted his bishop at f3, it allows his king the freedom to march queen-side. My king could march over to shore up the position, but I was not 100% sure I could safely handle the two pass-pawns on the e and g files with just my bishop.
